awd_titl_txt: Workshop/Collaborative Research: The Frontiers of Artificial Intelligence-Empowered Methods and Solutions to Urban Transportation Challenges
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides funds for a workshop that will gather researchers from transportation, computer science, and other relevant disciplines to explore the frontiers of artificial intelligence (AI)-empowered methods and solutions and future research directions to address urban transportation challenges. With the quickly growing quantity and variety of transportation data, AI technologies combined with other analytical methods have demonstrated a great potential to improve scientific understandings, transformative informed decisions, and innovative, proactive management solutions for urban transportation infrastructure systems, although significant challenges are also recognized. This workshop will attract distinguished experts from academia, industry, and government agencies to work together to identify the tremendous research and educational needs and challenges in developing AI-empowered methods and solutions to urban transportation challenges, and further stimulate transformative research and education activities in both transportation and AI communities.

This workshop includes two phases. Phase I has four podium sessions, one round-table discussion session, and one work session to investigate and document the potential and challenges of leveraging AI-empowered methods for fundamental urban transportation management research. Topics to discuss include traffic sensing and monitoring, congestion mitigation, shared mobility, user behavior, and associated equity and environmental issues. Phase II dedicates three podium sessions and one round-table discussion session to explore new education and training needs and directions for developing future workforce and responding to this big technology revolution in transportation. Overall, this two-phase workshop will produce a highly desired strategic research and education agenda for transportation and AI research communities to jointly develop AI-empowered methods and solutions to address urban transportation challenges and their workforce development needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Key Outcomes of the Workshops

Phase I Workshop: Titled "AI-empowered Methods for Fundamental Urban Transportation Management Research," this workshop was meticulously held at the University of Washington's Bill & Melinda Gates Center for Computer Science & Engineering on June 4-5, 2022. The workshop illuminated the critical research avenues within AI's role in urban transportation, concluding with the identification of key research needs, resources, and the challenges ahead. It underscored the necessity for more concerted efforts in crafting innovative AI-powered solutions for the Urban Transportation Infrastructure Systems (UTIS), marking a significant step toward research advancement in this field.

Phase II Workshop: With a pivot towards "Integrating AI in Transportation Infrastructure System Education and Workforce Development," this workshop took place at the University of Florida, Hilton University of Florida Conference Center, on December 15, 2022. The discussions were enriched with insights on integrating AI into the curriculum and workforce preparation for urban infrastructure management. A prioritized list of essential skills and competencies was identified, addressing the immediate and future requirements for the workforce to adeptly navigate and leverage emerging AI technologies.

Paper 1: Potentials and Challenges of AI-Empowered Solutions to Urban Transportation Infrastructure Systems (UTIS): NSF AI-Transportation Workshop Phase I

This paper delves into the transformative impact and challenges of embedding AI within urban transportation infrastructure systems (UTIS). Over the last decade, advancements in AI, combined with an influx of data related to traffic, have catalyzed significant improvements in the management, operations, and safety of transportation systems. Despite the achievements, the paper identifies areas such as data representativeness, transferability issues, and computational efficiency as lingering challenges. It advocates for bridging the gap between AI capabilities and the dynamic complexities of urban transportation systems, presenting a thoughtful exploration of future directions. The paper has been submitted to ASCE Journal of Transportation Engineering Part A: Systems and is currently under review.

Paper 2: Frontiers of Emerging AI Technologies Best Practices and Workforce Development in Transportation: NSF AI-Transportation Workshop Phase II

This paper envisions a roadmap for evolving the transportation workforce in the AI era, addressing the burgeoning opportunities and challenges. It emphasizes the integration of AI as a means to enhance efficiency, safety, and sustainability in transportation. However, it also sheds light on the significant hurdles like the scarcity of AI-qualified professionals and the need for updated skills and knowledge. The paper is a culmination of insights from the Phase II workshop, aimed at summarizing current AI practices in transportation, cataloging training resources, and strategizing educational program development tailored for AI in transportation. The paper has been submitted to ASCE Journal of Transportation Engineering Part A: Systems and is currently under review.

Broader Impacts of the Workshops

The two workshops, under the support of this project, generated influential broader impacts as follows.

Students Training: The two Ph.D. students, Chenlu Pu and Chenxi Liu, engaged in this project, have completed specialized training designed to sharpen their skills in summarizing key workshop findings and understanding the potential and challenges of AI technology applications in UTIS. This training exposed them to various cutting-edge AI technologies and applications in UTIS, and has proficiently prepared them to understand, analyze, interpret, and succinctly capture the rich thoughts and insights from the workshop sessions. They both helped draft the two papers that crystallized the essence and outcomes of the workshop. Through this involvement, Pu and Liu are making a significant impact on the field, simultaneously advancing their own research acumen and professional growth.

Webinar/Podium Presentations: In 2023, Dr. Lili Du and Dr. Yinhai Wang made significant contributions to the discourse on Artificial Intelligence (AI) in transportation, extending its implications across broader scientific and engineering domains. Dr. Du, through her active participation in pivotal meetings such as the TRB AED50 Committee on AI, the ASCE-T&DI Committee on AI in Transportation, and NSF Meta-Workshop on AI, emphasized the innovative integration and application of AI technologies within the transportation sector. Meanwhile, Dr. Wang delivered influential talks across various prestigious forums, including a White House-led dialogue and the ASCE Francis C. Turner Lecture, focusing on enhancing transportation safety, efficiency, and resilience through AI. Together, their efforts have positioned them at the forefront of leveraging AI for domain-specific enhancements and broader scientific breakthroughs.

Websites for Dissemination: To facilitate widespread dissemination and engagement, two websites have been dedicated to the NSF workshop series. These platforms offer extensive information on the workshops' objectives, locations, dates, speakers, and schedules, with a particular focus on AI's role in addressing transportation challenges across different modes. Future relevant activities will be posted and highlighted, such as conferences and workshops focusing on stimulating innovation in AI applications for transportation systems, along with plans to feature the published papers from the workshop series.

1) https://www.asce.org/communities/institutes-and-technical-groups/transportation-and-development-institute/committees/board-of-governors--t-di/emerging-technologies-council/artificial-intelligence-in-transportation-committee

2) https://sites.google.com/view/trbaed50/home?authuser=0
